awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Design of a Novel Photo-Thermo-Catalyst for Enhanced Activity and Stability of Dry Reforming of Methane
awd_abstract_narration:
Waste gases containing methane (CH4) and carbon dioxide (CO2) are produced from sources such as shale oil recovery, landfills, poultry and livestock farms, and other biogas sources.  One way to upgrade those gases is to react them in the presence of catalysts to transform them into simple gases such as carbon monoxide (CO) and hydrogen (H2) that can be further processed to a wide range of chemicals and fuels.  The catalyzed reaction between methane and carbon dioxide requires extremely high temperatures which makes it unattractive from an energy consumption standpoint.  An alternative approach is to utilize a combination of direct sunlight irradiation and heat generated via solar energy collectors to react the gases via simultaneous photocatalysis and thermal catalysis in a sustainable process driven solely by the sun's energy.  The project explores that concept using a novel approach known as thermo-photo-catalytic dry reforming of methane (DRM).  Specifically, the project will focus on catalyst designs that combine direct photocatalysis with thermal catalysis to achieve stable, highly-efficient DRM at temperatures much lower than those based on conventional fossil-fuel thermal catalysis alone.  The technology can potentially play a significant role in sustainably meeting our nation's future energy needs while simultaneously transforming the greenhouse gases - CH4 and CO2 = to useful fuels and chemicals.

The project will investigate several novel aspects of thermo-photo-catalytic DRM, including: (1) fabricating novel and stable catalysts that promote synergy between the photo- and thermo-catalytic effects via integration of a photocatalytically active support, inexpensive metal nanocatalysts dispersed on the support, and promoters to enhance catalytic activity and stability; (2) designing innovative nanostructures, i.e. an ultrathin porous overcoat on the catalyst via atomic layer deposition (ALD) to mitigate metal sintering and prevent coke formation; (3) understanding the fundamental mechanism of photo-thermo-catalysis at elevated temperatures through a combination of in situ DRIFTS (diffuse reflectance FTIR) spectroscopy, GC/MS measurement of the catalyst activity, and experiments using isotopically labeled CO2 and CH4 molecules; and (4) elucidating catalyst structure-activity-stability relationships through operando studies of metal valence, nanoparticle size, and overcoat pore structure changes, carried out utilizing in situ X-ray scattering, X-ray diffraction, and X-ray absorption spectroscopy at the Advanced Photon Source of Argonne National Laboratory. This research will advance fundamental understanding in the interdisciplinary areas of heterogeneous catalysis, surface chemistry, nanoscience, and spectroscopy.  In addition to the technical component of the research, the project will be supported by several programs at both institutions aimed at providing both high-school students and their teachers opportunities to develop research skills.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Merits parts:

Waste gases containing methane (CH4) and carbon dioxide (CO2) are produced from shale oil recovery, landfills, poultry, and livestock farms, and other biogas sources. One way to upgrade those gases is to react to them with catalysts to transform them into simple gases such as carbon monoxide (CO) and hydrogen (H2) that can be further processed into a wide range of chemicals and fuels. The catalyzed reaction between methane and carbon dioxide requires exceptionally high temperatures, making it unattractive from an energy consumption standpoint. At such a high temperature, the catalyst will face sintering and coking. The project explores that concept using a novel approach known as thermo-photo-catalytic dry reforming of methane (DRM). The PI collaborated with a group from TAMU to investigate several novel aspects of thermo-photo-catalytic DRM.

The PI focuses on the elucidating catalyst structure-activity-stability relationships through operando studies of metal valence, nanoparticle size, and overcoat pore structure changes, carried out utilizing in situ X-ray scattering, and X-ray absorption spectroscopy at the Advanced Photon Source of Argonne National Laboratory.  They found during the heating, SAXS could observe the nanopore formation. When the pore is formed, the surface of Pt catalyst gets oxidized immediately, observed by XAS. The in-situ, sequential SAXS/XANES experimental setup used in this work outlines an extremely useful technique for monitoring changes in the catalytic system. The results shown in this work will allow for better design and fabrication of ALD-supported metal catalysts. Understanding pore formation and how it affects catalyst stability and activity will greatly benefit the catalyst scientific community which has a variety of both industrial and commercial applications.

Broad impacts: Leveraging existing courses and capitalizing on existing infrastructures at NIU and ANL, the PI proposes to institutionalize introductory-level nanoscience and X-ray experiments relevant to the undergraduate courses into existing curriculums with laboratory assignments. The PI selects the second-semester general chemistry lab (CHEM 212) and the upper-division Special topic-Synchrotron X-ray Characterization (CHEM600/400) courses as the initial vehicles for implementing this process. The PI continues to organize the ANL tour for the undergraduate students from NSF-REU program, NSF-STEM program, and the Office of Student Engagement & Experiential Learning Division at NIU. So they can receive hands-on training in cutting-edge facilities such as APS and CNM. The PI routinely mentors a diverse group of undergraduate researchers to conduct research in his group. In particular, he is committed to bringing research experience to freshman and sophomore undergraduates. All his undergraduate students were recruited before their junior years through NIU research rookie program. In this project, the graduate student is involved with X-ray scattering and X-ray spectroscopy. Such research experience at Argonne will benefit the students? career development.

 

Summary:

The objective of this research is to design an efficient and stable catalyst that can maximize the photo-thermo synergistic effects for DRM reaction under concentrated solar conditions (up to 50 suns), to explore the photochemistry and reaction mechanism at elevated temperatures (up to 800 ?C), and to correlate catalyst activity and stability with materials nanostructures through in operando studies. The PIs have published six high-impact papers: Catalysis Today, 2023, 409, 31-41; J. Mater. Chem. A, 2022,10, 7896-7910; ACS Catalysis, 2021, 11, 2605-2619;  Small Methods, 2021, 2001194; Applied Catalysis B: Environmental, 2020, 118189; Small 2022, 2106017. 

Two graduate students have been well-trained in this project. One graduate student Erik Sarnello has been well-trained at APS beamlines and CNM. He has received a competitive scholarship from the XVII International Small-Angle Scattering Conference to attend this meeting in 2018 and gave a presentation. The student has recently published over 30 papers, including Nature Communication, ACS Catalysis, and Nano Energy. In addition, he has been awarded the distinguished Dissertation Completion Fellowship at NIU and selected by DOE to attend 2020 National Neutron and X-ray summer school for his outstanding research activity. Also, he has won the prestigious DOE Office of Science Graduate Student Research (SCGSR) Award and now works at ANL as a postdoc. Another graduate student Lingzhe Fang has published 6 first-author high-impact papers and more than 20 co-author's papers, including Nature Catalyst, Nature Communication, etc. He has been supported by this NSF to conduct an internship at Lawrence Berkeley National Lab in 2022 and won the Dissertation Completion Fellowship in 2023. He is selected by DOE to attend the 2022 National Neutron and X-ray summer school for his outstanding research
